facts.text: Appellant is a company doing business in general insurance. Respondent carries on business as a common carrier of goods.

Respondent took out three transit policies of insurance renewable every year from appellant. Relevant policy is freight policy No. CL1/RE-P/257 taken in January 1969 against risk of loss or damage to goods during transit.

In June 1971, respondent declared consignment of 185 packages of general merchandise worth approx. Rs. 1,10,000 for transit from Calcutta to Assam and Tripura, paid premium, goods insured under policy.

On evening of 29-6-71, consignment loaded in Truck No. WGH-8261, truck left Calcutta for Gauhati. Owner informed respondent of robbery after reaching Barasat on night of 29-6-71; truck, driver, merchandise not traced.

On 1-7-1971, respondent sent letters to Jarabagan Police Station, Assistant Commissioner of Police Intelligence Branch Lall Bazar, Deputy Commissioner of Police Intelligence Branch about truck not reaching Beniagram, truck/driver/merchandise untraced. Copy to appellant received by appellant on 2-7-1971.
On 1-7-1971 and 21-9-1971, respondent lodged claim for loss with appellant.
On 3-7-1971, appellant asked respondent for particulars: name/address of vehicle owner, driver etc.
On 21-9-1971, respondent informed appellant that info supplied to appellant's agent Mr. A.L. Chopra on 5-7-1971.
On 10-10-1971, appellant wrote that without police investigation report, cannot proceed.
Appellant received copy of Barasat police investigation report on 12-5-1972 stating alleged robbery was false.
On 4-8-1972, appellant sent letter stating contents of Barasat report, asked for Jarabagan/Lall Bazar reports.
On 16-2-1973, appellant disclaimed liability under policy for loss of consignment.
On 30-3-1973, respondent asked for grounds of disclaimer.
On 30-5-1973, appellant replied nothing to add to 16-2-1973 letter.
Respondent had dealings with appellant since 1958, no prior claim rejected.
First week June 1973, respondent gave papers to solicitors M/s. Banerji & Co. for arbitration steps.
On or about 15-6-1973, solicitors opined appellant's disclaimer vague, might rely on clause 12; advised nominate arbitrator due to appellant's delay.
28-6-1973, solicitors briefed counsel for opinion.
16-7-1973, counsel opined apply for extension under s.37(4) Arbitration Act; respondent informed 18-7-1973.
25-7-1973, solicitors sent brief to counsel to draft petition; received 30-7-1973.
17-8-1973, respondent filed application in Calcutta High Court under s.37(4) Arbitration Act for extension of time to refer dispute to arbitration till 15 days after court order.
14-1-1974, Calcutta High Court allowed application, extended time to refer to arbitration within fortnight from that date.
Respondent filed suit against truck owner in July 1972 for recovery of loss; paid claims to consignors.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court had power under s.37(4) of the Arbitration Act, 1940 to extend time for referring dispute to arbitration, and if so, whether exercised properly in the circumstances.

petitioner_arguments.text: S.37(4) of the Act had no application, court had no jurisdiction to extend time, and even if jurisdiction, no valid grounds for extension. In circumstances, no undue hardship to respondent if time not extended.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Clause 12 of policy; s.37(4) Arbitration Act

respondent_arguments.text: Reasons for delay after receiving disclaimer letter: sought specific grounds, consulted solicitors and counsel; appellant's vague disclaimer and delay contributed.

court_reasoning.text: Clause 12 of policy deems claim abandoned if not referred to arbitration within 3 months of disclaimer. S.37(4) allows extension if undue hardship otherwise caused.
court_reasoning.key_observation: English precedents interpret 'undue hardship' liberally: consider delay extent, fault, amount at stake, prejudice to other side.

court_reasoning.text: Respondent's conduct reasonable: prompt claims, police intimation, inquired grounds of rejection, consulted lawyers promptly after final vague reply. No prior rejections in long dealings. Barasat report doesn't prove fraud; suits filed show bonafides.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No material prejudice to appellant; amount at stake high, delay reasons valid, consequences disproportionate to any fault.

court_reasoning.text: High Court exercised discretion properly; appeal dismissed but further time extended to appellant for arbitrator nomination.

holdings.text: High Court had jurisdiction under s.37(4) and properly exercised discretion to extend time as undue hardship would be caused otherwise.

precedents_cited.case_name: Steamship Co. of 1912 etc. v. Indo-American Grain Co. etc.
precedents_cited.relevance: Strict view: must be very special circumstances for extension beyond ordinary hardship.

precedents_cited.case_name: Watney, Comba, Reid Co. v. E. A. L. Dover Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Mere barring of claim not undue hardship; court cannot remove contractual bar.

precedents_cited.case_name: F.E. Hookway Co. Ltd. v. H.W.H. Hopper Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Delay not claimant's fault = undue hardship; consider sub-contract losses.

precedents_cited.case_name: Stanhope Steamship Co. Ltd. v. British Phosphate Commissioners
precedents_cited.relevance: Undue hardship if oppressive/out of proportion to fault; amount and delay reasons material.

precedents_cited.case_name: Liberian Shipping etc. v. A King & Sons
precedents_cited.relevance: Liberal view of undue hardship: excusable inadvertence, no prejudice, even if claimant's fault if disproportionate; list factors like blame, amount, delay length, prejudice.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Court may extend time for arbitration if undue hardship otherwise caused, notwithstanding expiry.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court's order extending time upheld. Further time of one month from judgment date extended to appellant to nominate arbitrator.

key_quotes.text: "Undue must mean something which is not merited by the conduct of the claimant, or is very much disproportionate to it."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We do not think that any material prejudice would be caused to the appellant by extending the time. There would be undue hardship if time is not extended."
key_quotes.speaker: court
